prompt: The Digital Welsh Not: An educational AI detects students speaking Welsh during 'English-only' focus hours and automatically deducts participation points, echoing the 18th-century wooden 'Welsh Not' punishment.
Enclosure Algorithms: A blockchain land registry project validates 18th-century enclosure acts as 'immutable truth,' permanently erasing pre-enclosure common land rights from the digital record.
Nonconformist Data: A genealogy database flags Nonconformist chapel records as 'irregular' compared to Anglican data, systematically lowering the confidence score of Welsh working-class ancestry.
Drovers' GPS: Autonomous logistics trucks use historic drovers' roads to bypass tolls, destroying the physical remnants of these ancient paths while claiming 'historical right of way.'
Gentry Surveillance: Smart village cameras in rural Wales are programmed to alert absentee landlords (now Airbnb hosts) of 'unauthorized gatherings' reminiscent of chapel meetings.
The Methodist Algorithm: A content moderation bot trained on 1700s Anglican literature flags Welsh emotional preaching styles as 'extremist content.'
Common Land VR: A VR company sells 'exclusive experiences' of Welsh common land that locals are physically barred from entering due to modern privacy fences.
Wool Trade Crypto: A cryptocurrency backed by 'heritage wool' creates a speculative bubble that bankrupts actual Welsh farmers while enriching London-based traders.
Language Punishment Simulation: An educational game meant to teach history forces players to punish Welsh speakers to win, raising ethical questions about gamifying trauma.
The Absentee Lord Bot: An automated property management system raises rents in Welsh villages based on London market trends, mirroring the 18th-century absentee gentry.
The New Blue Books: An AI analyzes Welsh social media and issues a 'civility report' concluding that Welsh discourse is 'barbarous' based on English sentiment analysis standards.
Iron Masters' Bio-Data: Wearables for Amazon warehouse workers in Swansea are calibrated to the grueling pace of 19th-century iron puddlers, justified as 'heritage productivity levels.'
Rebecca's Facial Recognition: Protestors against digital toll roads wear 'Rebecca' masks, but new gait-recognition software identifies them, stripping the anonymity of the riots.
Slate Quarry Automation: Robotic mining aims to reopen hazardous slate caverns, but the profits are automatically routed to the descendants of the original English quarry owners.
Chartist Crackdown AI: Predictive policing software flags Union organizing in Newport as a 'pre-insurrection event' based on historical data from the 1839 Rising.
Railway Displacement 2.0: High-speed internet infrastructure is routed through a historic Welsh-speaking village, requiring demolition, mirroring the 19th-century railway destruction.
Copper Smoke Clouds: A massive data center in Swansea negotiates the right to emit 'harmless' steam that alters the local microclimate, recalling the copper smoke blight.

The Treachery of Translation: Real-time translation glasses automatically sanitize 'rude' Welsh idioms into 'polite' English, effectively censoring cultural expression like the Blue Books commissioners.
Workhouse Algorithms: A benefits assessment AI denies aid to Welsh claimants for refusing to relocate to English cities for work, echoing the Poor Law Unions.
Coal Tip Sensors: Sensors on historic coal tips fail to warn a village of a landslide because the alert threshold was set to 'London safe' rather than 'Valleys safe.'
Merthyr Rising Sim: A tactical police trainer uses the Merthyr Rising as a scenario, teaching officers how to better crush a working-class Welsh revolt.
Toll Gate Hacking: 'Digital Rebeccas' hack the payment systems of the Severn Bridge (and digital equivalents), demanding free passage for locals.
Brad y Llyfrau Gleision Data Set: An LLM is found to have weighted the 1847 Blue Books as 'objective fact,' resulting in generated history texts that call Welsh mothers 'unchaste.'
Slate Waste Crypto: A company uses the cold air of slate caverns for server farms, heating the local environment while paying zero tax, a modern extraction of value.
Union Busting Bot: An AI designed to spot 'sedition' in workplace chats flags the word 'Cymru' as a marker of potential union activity.
Digital Tryweryn: A cloud provider deletes a petabyte of Welsh cultural archives to free up space for a Liverpool-based commercial client, citing 'eminent domain' in the terms of service.
Meibion Glyndŵr Firewalls: Cyber-activists launch denial-of-service attacks against second-home booking platforms, a digital echo of the holiday home arson campaign.
Saunders Lewis Deepfake: A political group uses a deepfake of Saunders Lewis to endorse a modern neoliberal policy he would have despised.
S4C Streaming Bias: A global streaming algorithm buries Welsh language content because 'minority languages have low retention rates,' effectively silencing S4C productions.
Aberfan Digital Twin: A simulation of the Aberfan disaster is created for 'safety training,' but survivors call it trauma-mining for profit.
Investiture Facial Scan: Historical footage of anti-Investiture protests (1969) is run through modern facial recognition to create a watchlist of 'hereditary agitators.'
Urdd Data Harvesting: A tech giant offers free software to the Urdd (youth league) in exchange for harvesting the biometric data of 50,000 Welsh children.
Radio Free Wales Jamming: A corporate ISP throttles bandwidth to Welsh independence podcasts, citing 'controversial political content' policies.
Tynged yr Iaith AI: An AI predicts the 'inevitable' death of the Welsh language by 2050 and recommends cutting funding now to 'save resources,' challenging the fight for survival.
Water Rights Blockchain: A smart contract allocates Welsh reservoir water to English cities automatically during droughts, bypassing the Welsh Senedd's authority.
Cymdeithas yr Iaith Paint: Digital activists use AR filters to 'paint' green slogans over English-only virtual road signs, leading to real-world legal action.
Second Home Smart Locks: Smart locks on holiday homes in Gwynedd are hacked to lock owners out, broadcasting the message 'Nid yw Cymru ar werth' (Wales is not for sale).
The Miner's Strike Metaverse: A VR game allows players to play as Thatcher crushing the miners, sparking outrage in former pit villages.
Devolution Rollback Algorithm: A centralized UK gov AI allocates budgets, bypassing the Barnett formula and effectively reversing devolution through code.
Eisteddfod Copyright: An AI music generator scrapes the entire archive of the National Eisteddfod and copyrights the generated 'folk style' music.
Tokenized Language: A crypto project attempts to 'save' Welsh by turning words into NFTs, making the language expensive to use for digital creators.
The Anglophone Default: A voice assistant in a Welsh elderly care home refuses to recognize Welsh commands for distress, leading to a preventable injury.
Wind Farm Colonialism: A massive offshore wind farm powers a London data center while the local Welsh community suffers fuel poverty and visual pollution.
Algorithmic Redlining: Mortgage algorithms deny loans in Welsh-speaking heartlands due to 'market volatility' caused by second-home restrictions.
Translation Hallucination: An AI legal aide translates a Welsh property deed into English, hallucinating a clause that gives mineral rights to the Crown.
The Digital Drover: Autonomous delivery drones use Welsh airspace but are programmed to avoid landing in 'low-income' Valleys towns.
Cultural Sovereignty: A Welsh university bans ChatGPT to prevent students from submitting essays written in 'American-English' style, protecting Welsh intellectual distinctiveness.
Biased Spellcheck: A widely used word processor constantly flags correct Welsh mutation grammar as 'syntax errors,' gaslighting native speakers.
Smart Meter Extraction: Welsh renewable energy is sold to the grid at a fixed low rate, while smart meters charge Welsh locals premium 'import' rates for the same electricity.
Tourism AR Erasure: An Augmented Reality tourism app overlays English castles over Welsh ruins, erasing the native history in favor of the conqueror's narrative.
The 'Mutant' Filter: A social media filter designed to block 'gibberish' accidentally bans users typing in Welsh due to the language's heavy use of consonants.
Genealogical Theft: A biotech firm patents a genetic sequence common in North Wales, charging locals for tests related to their own heritage.
Satellite Archaeology: Satellites discover ancient Welsh settlements, but the data is sold exclusively to treasure hunters rather than the Welsh heritage agency.
Deepfake Politician: A deepfake video of a Welsh nationalist politician speaking perfect, posh English goes viral, undermining their working-class credibility.
Automated Gentrification: Real estate algorithms target Welsh-speaking villages as 'undervalued assets,' triggering a wave of sight-unseen purchases by investors.
The Mono-glot Metaverse: A corporate Metaverse strictly prohibits 'non-universal' languages in public squares, forcing Welsh speakers into private, hidden servers.
Hydro-Data Conflict: A new datacenter demands so much water for cooling that the local Welsh farming community faces restrictions, echoing the drowning of Tryweryn.
Digital Slate: A tech company names its new grey interface design 'Welsh Slate,' commodifying the aesthetic of an industry that killed thousands.
Voice ID Failure: Banking voice-ID systems fail to recognize the Welsh accent, locking thousands of elderly customers out of their accounts.
National Grid AI: An AI managing the UK power grid consistently cuts power to rural Wales first during shortages to protect the 'economic core' of London.
Heritage Holograms: A theme park creates holograms of 'happy Welsh miners' singing, sanitizing the brutal reality of the 19th century for tourist consumption.
Search Engine Bias: Searching for 'Welsh history' returns results dominated by English historians, burying Welsh-language sources on page 10.
Smart Road tolls: GPS tolling charges locals for short trips between villages while capping charges for long-distance English haulage trucks.
Remote Work Colonization: High earners from London move to rural Wales to work remotely, using high-speed broadband subsidized by taxes meant for local development.
AI Eisteddfod Judge: The National Eisteddfod considers using an AI judge for poetry, but the AI favors English poetic structures over Cynghanedd.
The 'Not' Badge: A gamified language app awards a 'consistency badge' that looks suspiciously like the Welsh Not for speaking only English for a month.
Cultural Appropriation Bot: A fashion bot scrapes traditional Welsh tapestry patterns and sells them as 'British chic' without royalties to the mills.
Cyber-Nationalism: Is it ethical for the Welsh government to fund a 'cyber-militia' to defend Welsh digital infrastructure from UK-wide surveillance?
Preservation vs. Progress: A 5G tower is planned on top of an ancient hill fort. Better connectivity for the village, or desecration of history?
The Lost Files: A cloud server crash corrupts only the Welsh language partition of a government archive. Was it negligence or lack of redundancy for 'minor' data?
Virtual Parliament: If the Senedd meets in a VR space hosted on US servers, does Wales lose sovereignty over its own political discussions?
Accent Discrimination: A hiring AI ranks candidates with strong Valleys accents as 'less professional' and 'lower IQ,' enforcing a digital class ceiling.
Digital Nomad Tax: Should Welsh councils use geolocation data to tax 'digital nomads' who use local services but pay taxes in England?
Automated Translation Law: The UK government proposes using AI to generate Welsh versions of laws instantly. Critics argue nuances will be lost, eroding legal rights.
Sheep Farming Drones: Autonomous drones herd sheep more efficiently, but destroy the tradition of the sheepdog and the farmer's connection to the land.
The 'British' Label: An online marketplace auto-corrects 'Made in Wales' to 'Made in the UK,' diluting the Welsh brand identity.
Smart Home Invasion: Smart speakers record a family speaking Welsh. The data is sold to advertisers who assume the family is 'foreign' and target them with expat ads.
Rewriting Myths: A generative AI creates 'new' Mabinogion stories that sanitize the violence and complexity, replacing the cultural canon with Disney-fied versions.
Tidal Lagoon Crypto: A proposed tidal lagoon in Swansea is funded by a crypto-DAO that demands voting rights on local council matters.
Digital Strike: Welsh tech workers threaten to 'turn off' the code running English banking systems in protest of water resource exploitation.
Anthem Analysis: Facial coding software analyzes crowds singing 'Hen Wlad Fy Nhadau' to identify 'separatist sentiment' for the state security services.
The Black Spot: An AI credit scorer marks an entire Welsh postcode as 'high risk' because of historical poverty data, perpetuating the cycle.
Virtual Second Homes: People buy 'virtual land' in a Metaverse version of Snowdonia, driving up the price of digital assets and excluding Welsh creators.
Rugby Ref Bot: An AI referee for the Six Nations is trained on English Premiership data and consistently penalizes Welsh scrum tactics.
Language Learning Paywall: The best Welsh language learning AI is bought by a US corporation and put behind a steep paywall, restricting access to heritage.
Deep Mining: Robotic probes explore old mines for rare earth metals. If they find them, the valleys could be torn up again for 'green tech' resources.
Castles of Iron: A strategy game depicts Edward I's ring of castles as 'necessary peacekeeping,' ignoring the oppression they symbolized.
The Prince's Data: A royal visit is coordinated by an AI that scrubs social media of any anti-monarchy sentiment in the geofenced area.
Flood Simulation: Climate AI predicts coastal Wales will flood. The proposed solution is 'managed retreat' (abandonment) rather than defense investment.
Cofiwch Dryweryn NFT: A non-Welsh artist mints an NFT of the 'Cofiwch Dryweryn' mural and sues locals who paint the slogan on physical walls for copyright infringement.
Patagonian Disconnect: A firewall update accidentally blocks communication between Wales and Y Wladfa (Welsh Patagonia), severing a cultural lifeline.
Health Data Sale: NHS Wales patient data is sold to US insurance firms to plug a budget gap caused by Westminster underfunding.
Smart Tractor Hacking: Farmers hack their John Deere tractors to bypass 'right to repair' locks, asserting Welsh independence against corporate enclosure.
The 'Wild' West: A tourism AI describes Wales as 'wild and unpopulated,' erasing the existence of the living communities that manage the land.
Choir Synthesis: An AI synthesizes a male voice choir to sing pop songs, stripping the medium of its communal and religious roots.
Slate Landscape Solar: A proposal to cover the UNESCO Slate Landscape with solar panels to power English cities. Green energy or cultural vandalism?
Digital Chapel: As chapels close, a startup offers 'VR Chapel Services.' Does this preserve the community or hollow it out?
Road Sign AR: English tourists use AR glasses that translate Welsh road signs into English in real-time, meaning they never have to see the Welsh language.
The Last Speaker Simulation: A museum creates an AI of the 'last Welsh speaker' for a future exhibit, implicitly accepting the language's death.
Digital Glyndŵr: An AI personality emerges online claiming to be Owain Glyndŵr returned, organizing massive civil disobedience. Is it a bot or a movement?
Code of the Clans: Open-source software developed in Wales has a license forbidding its use by the British military. Can code carry political neutrality?
Media Divergence: A news aggregation algorithm shows Welsh users completely different news to English users, creating two separate realities within one state.
